infodynamics.measures.discrete

Class PredictiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.discrete.PredictiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete

  • public class PredictiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete
extends java.lang.Object

    Predictive information calculator for univariate discrete (int[]) data. See definition of Predictive information (PI) by Bialek et al. below, also is a form of the Excess Entropy (see Crutchfield and Feldman below), Basically, PI is the mutual information between the past state of a time-series process X and its future state. The past state at time n is represented by an embedding vector of k values from X_n backwards, each separated by \tau steps, giving X^k_n = [ X_{n-(k-1)\tau}, ... , X_{n-\tau}, X_n]. We call k the embedding dimension, and \tau the embedding delay (only delay = 1 is implemented at the moment). The future state at time n is defined similarly into the future: each separated by \tau steps, giving X^k+_n = [ X_{n+1}, X_{n+\tau}, X_{n+(k-1)\tau}]. PI is then the mutual information between X^k_n and X^k+_n.

    Usage of the class is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator: PredictiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete(int, int);
    2. Initialise the calculator using initialise();
    3. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using one or more calls to sets of addObservations(int[]) methods, then
    4. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average entropy: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • local entropy values, such as computeLocal(int[]);
      • and variants of these.
    5. As an alternative to steps 3 and 4, the user may undertake standalone computation from a single set of observations, via e.g.: computeLocal(int[]), computeAverageLocal(int[]) etc.
    6. Return to step 2 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    TODO Inherit from SingleAgentMeasureDiscreteInContextOfPastCalculator as ActiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete does; Tidy up the Javadocs for the methods, which are somewhat preliminary

    References:

    • Bialek, W., Nemenman, I., and Tishby, N., "Complexity through nonextensivity", Physica A, 302, 89-99. (2001).
    • J. P. Crutchfield, D. P. Feldman, "Regularities Unseen, Randomness Observed: Levels of Entropy Convergence", Chaos, Vol. 13, No. 1. (2003), pp. 25-54.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • PredictiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete

        public PredictiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete(int numDiscreteValues,
                                       int blockLength)
        Construct a new instance
        Parameters:
        numDiscreteValues - number of quantisation levels for each variable. E.g. binary variables are in base-2.
        blockLength - embedded history length of the past and future to use - this is k in Schreiber's notation.

      • computeLocal

        public double[] computeLocal(int[] timeSeries)
        Standalone routine to compute local predictive information from a time series. Return an array of local values. First k and last k-1 rows are zeros.
        Parameters:
        timeSeries - time series array of states
        Returns:
        time series of local predictive information values

      • computeLocal

        public double[][] computeLocal(int[][] timeSeries)
        Standalone routine to compute local predictive information across a 2D spatiotemporal time series of the observations of homogeneous agents. This method to be called for homogeneous agents only, as all observations are pooled together. First k and last k-1 rows are zeros.
        Parameters:
        timeSeries - 2D array of states (first index is time, second is variable id)
        Returns:
        multivariate time series of local predictive information values (1st index is time, second is variable id)

      • computeLocal

        Parameters:
        timeSeries - 2D array of states (first index is time, second and third are variable ids)
        Returns:
        multivariate time series of local predictive information values (1st index is time, second and third are variable ids)

      • computeLocal

        public double[] computeLocal(int[][] timeSeries,
                    int col)
        Standalone routine to compute local predictive information for one agent in a 2D spatiotemporal array of the states of agents First k and last k-1 rows are zeros. This method should be used for heterogeneous agents.
        Parameters:
        timeSeries - 2D array of states (first index is time, second is variable id)
        col - index of the agent whose local values should be calculated
        Returns:
        time series of local predictive information values for the given agent id

      • computeLocal

                    int agentIndex1,
                    int agentIndex2)

        agentIndex1 - row index of agent
        agentIndex2 - column index of agent
        Returns:
        time series of local predictive information values for the given agent id

        Returns:

      • computePastValue

        public int computePastValue(int[] x,
                   int t)
        Utility function to compute the combined past values of x up to and including time step t (i.e. (x_{t-k+1}, ... ,x_{t-1},x_{t}))
        Parameters:
        x - time series
        t - time step to compute joint past value up to
        Returns:
        joint discrete value computed from the (x_{t-k+1}, ... ,x_{t-1},x_{t})

      • computePastValue

        public int computePastValue(int[][] x,
                   int i,
                   int t)
        Utility function to compute the combined past values of x up to and including time step t for a given variable number within x (i.e. (x_{t-k+1,i}, ... ,x_{t-1,i},x_{t,i}))
        Parameters:
        x - 2D multivariate time series
        i - column or agent number within x.
        t - time step to compute joint past value up to
        Returns:
        joint discrete value computed from the (x_{t-k+1,i}, ... ,x_{t-1,i},x_{t,i}))

      • computePastValue

        public int computePastValue(int[][][] x,
                   int i,
                   int j,
                   int t)
        Utility function to compute the combined past values of x up to and including time step t for a given variable number within x (i.e. (x_{t-k+1,i,j}, ... ,x_{t-1,i,j},x_{t,i,j}))
        Parameters:
        x - 3D multivariate time series
        i - 1st index to identify agent within x.
        i - 2nd index to identify agent within x.
        t - time step to compute joint past value up to
        Returns:
        joint discrete value computed from the (x_{t-k+1,i}, ... ,x_{t-1,i},x_{t,i}))
